title: American_Top_40_1988_March_26th
description:
"We're counting down the 40 top hits in the 50 states from Devil's Den, California, to Devil's Tower, Wyoming; from Devil's Elbow, Missouri, to Devil's Elbow, Missouri; from Devils Lake, North Dakota, to Devil's Track Lake, Minnesota. Up four notches to number 12, 'Devil Inside' - INXS."

American Top 40 with Casey Kasem aired on radio from July 4, 1970 until August 6, 1988. This recording is a rebroadcast from internet radio.


In this countdown:

Even though Louis Armstrong (at number 33 with "What A Wonderful World") died in 1971, he set a new record for longest span of time between top 40 appearances. Casey tells why.

There is a song by the first solo act in history to hit the top 10 in her teens, 20's, 30's, and 40's. Casey plays a bit a hit from each decade.

One artist in the countdown was once part of a band whose music was unmistakably diatonic, suggested the mixolydian mode, and a false modal frame. Casey explains.

Cherelle (at number 29 with Alexander OÃ¢â‚¬â„¢Neal with "Never Knew Love Like This") along with her cousin promised as children that if one of them made it in the record business, the other had to also. Her cousin has a song in this countdown.

This is the week Michael Jackson (at number 1 with "Man In The Mirror") makes chart history as the first artist to get four number 1 hits from one album (from his album "Bad").
